Course Description: This course deals with the application of the fundamental concepts of programming using a high-level programming language (typically Java or C++). It covers more advanced programming concepts such as arrays, file handling, and an introduction to object-oriented programming principles including classes and objects.
Outcome Text: Apply advanced programming concepts such as multi-dimensional arrays and string manipulation to solve complex problems.
Design and implement simple applications utilizing object-oriented principles like encapsulation and file I/O operations.

Course Description: This laboratory course accompanies the lecture component on Data Structures. It focuses on the implementation of various data structures such as linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, and graphs, as well as the practical application of sorting and searching algorithms.
Outcome Text: Implement linear data structures including stacks, queues, and linked lists in a high-level programming language.
Analyze and implement non-linear data structures (trees, graphs) and apply appropriate sorting and searching algorithms for efficiency.

Course Description: This course provides hands-on experience in the design and implementation of database systems. It covers data modeling (ER Diagrams), relational database design, and the use of SQL (Structured Query Language) for data definition, manipulation, and control.
Outcome Text: Design an Entity-Relationship (ER) diagram that accurately models a given business problem or scenario.
Construct complex SQL queries to create, read, update, and delete data within a relational database management system.

Course Description: This course explores the practical aspects of various computing platforms, focusing on operating system environments, scripting, and the deployment of applications across different platforms (Web, Mobile, or Desktop). It may include administration and configuration tasks.
Outcome Text: Configure and manage operating system environments to support application deployment and system administration tasks.
Develop and deploy simple scripts or applications that run across multiple computing platforms using virtualization or containerization tools.

Course Description: This course provides an introduction to the design and analysis of algorithms. It covers asymptotic analysis (Big O notation), fundamental algorithm design techniques (divide-and-conquer, greedy methods, dynamic programming), and explores specific algorithms for sorting, searching, and graph problems.
Outcome Text: Analyze the asymptotic performance of algorithms using Big O notation and determine the time complexity of simple algorithms.
Design efficient algorithms using appropriate techniques such as greedy methods or dynamic programming to solve computational problems.

Course Description: The laboratory component focuses on the practical implementation of algorithms discussed in the lecture. Students will write programs to implement sorting, searching, and graph algorithms, and empirically compare their execution times against theoretical analysis.
Outcome Text: Implement fundamental sorting and searching algorithms in a high-level programming language and benchmark their running times.
Develop and test complex programs that utilize graph algorithms (like BFS, DFS, Dijkstra) or dynamic programming solutions for real-world scenarios.
